item.description:
Suggested by Joan Lloyd.  Really good film. I'll be there around 7:15 pm.

 

Lovers of art, mysteries, prehistory, and the extraordinary films of Werner Herzog: prepare to be blown away by an unforgettable movie experience. Herzog's ever-curious spirit brings his audience along on his quest to film 30,000 year old paintings, discovered deep in the Chauvet Cave in southeastern France in 1994. While the oldest visual artwork known to have been created by humans is in itself a revelation, the director's desire to find the moment of conception of the creative impulse links these paintings with everything - from Van Gogh to the films of Fred Astaire - that follows. With the addition of a rapturous, hypnotic score by Ernst Reijseger, Cave of Forgotten Dreams is a modern-day sacred work for the secular imagination. "I was not prepared. Facing the paintings, it's just sheer awe how beautiful and how accomplished they are." - Werner Herzog, NPR's Fresh Air

group.name: Beyond the Multiplex: Hartford's Indie and Foreign Film fans

item.name: Cave of Forgotton Dreams
